Full Triage Effectiveness Simulation for Research

Source: R/sim_te.R
sim_te_alt.Rd

Performs a complete simulation of emergency department patient flow, calculating theoretical wait times for all patients regardless of their time-critical status. This function is designed for research purposes when complete queue behavior analysis is needed, and is more computationally intensive than the standard sim_te function.

Usage

sim_te_alt(df, tte = TRUE, btte = FALSE, n_workers = 1)

Arguments

df

A data frame containing patient data, including:

  • id: Unique patient identifier

  • arrival_minute: Minutes since start of study period until patient arrival

  • resolve_minute: Minutes since start until patient sees physician

  • priority: Original triage priority

  • priority_binary: Binary priority (typically 1 for high, 2 for low)

  • loset: Logical indicating if patient is time-critical per LOSET criteria

  • observed_wait_time: Actual waiting time in minutes

tte

Logical. If TRUE, calculates Theoretical Triage Efficacy (TTE). Default is TRUE.

btte

Logical. If TRUE, calculates Binary Theoretical Triage Efficacy (BTTE). Default is FALSE.

n_workers

Integer. Number of cores to use for parallel processing. Default is 1.

Value

A data frame with the original patient data and additional columns:

  • theoretical_wait_time: Simulated wait time based on original priorities (if tte=TRUE)

  • binary_theoretical_wait_time: Simulated wait time based on binary priorities (if btte=TRUE)

Details

Unlike sim_te which optimizes performance by focusing only on segments containing time-critical cases, sim_te_alt simulates waiting times for all patients. This makes it more suitable for research purposes such as:

  • Analyzing complete queue behavior patterns

  • Studying wait time distributions for non-time-critical patients

  • Validating simulation methodology

  • Investigating effects of different priority schemes

The simulation operates in a non-preemptive manner, treating physician contacts as available time slots and processing patients strictly according to priority and arrival order. While this provides complete information about theoretical queue behavior, it is computationally more intensive than sim_te and may not be necessary for standard TE calculations.

Note that while sim_te_alt calculates wait times for all patients, it produces identical TE values to sim_te since TE metrics depend only on the wait times of time-critical patients relative to the overall mean.

See also

sim_te for the optimized simulation approach recommended for standard TE calculations

Examples

if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{
# Basic usage with default settings
results <- sim_te_alt(patient_data)

# Calculate both TTE and BTTE with parallel processing
results <- sim_te_alt(patient_data,
                      tte = TRUE,
                      btte = TRUE,
                      n_workers = 4)
} # }
